title: Cost of Draft Local Plan Consultant for Sheffield City Council

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please inform me of the total cost of SCC's Whole Plan Viability Appraisal report recently carried out by
http://www.hdhplanning.co.uk/
in preparation for the Local Draft Plan.
I am informed by Simon Vincent of the Planning Service that If the Council decided to require more than 10% BNG, it would have to reduce requirements under other policies. Please could you fully reference the relevant government regulations enforcing this.
Thank you.
Nicola Gilbert

Dear Nicola Gilbert,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Cost of Draft Local
Plan Consultant for Sheffield City Council which we received on
01/02/2023.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request below:
1. The total cost of the Whole Plan Viability Appraisal (WPVA) was
£29,500.
2. The National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF), paragraph 34 says that:
‘Plans should set out the contributions expected from development. This
should include setting out the levels and types of affordable housing
provision required, along with other infrastructure (such as that needed
for education, health, transport, flood and water management, green and
digital infrastructure). Such policies should not undermine the
deliverability of the plan.’
It is usual practice for local planning authorities to carry out an
assessment of the cumulative impact of the policies in the local plan on
development viability.  If development cannot be shown to be economically
viable, then it is unlikely it will be deliverable.  The WPVA will used as
evidence at the public examination to demonstrate that the plan is viable
and would, therefore, be ‘effective’. The effectiveness of the plan is one
of the four tests of soundness set out in paragraph 35 of the NPPF.
Ultimately, the decision to set 10% Biodiversity Net Gain (BNG) was a
judgment made by Members on the advice of officers, taking into account
the findings in the WPVA. A number of different policy objectives had to
be balanced – for example, the need to provide affordable housing, the
need to provide wheelchair adaptable housing and the need to cut carbon
dioxide emissions.  Although the Draft Plan requires developers to provide
10% net gain, Policy GS6 does make clear that higher levels of BNG will be
required where:
• there is a particular ecological need in that location based on
evidence in a biodiversity/nature recovery action plan or as part of
the Local Nature Recovery Network mapping, or
• there is evidence of rare/protected species within, or close to, the
development site; or
• the site starts with very low or nil existing biodiversity value
